author: By Nelson D. Schwartz, Patrick McGeehan, Nicole Hong and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: New York Faces Lasting Economic Toll Even as Pandemic Passes
description: The city’s prosperity is heavily dependent on patterns of work and travel that may be irreversibly altered.
content: As the national economy recovers from the pandemic and begins to take off, New York City is lagging, with changing patterns of work and travel threatening the engines that have long powered its jobs and prosperity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
title: In Rift With Biden, a Dramatic Show of Force by a Conservative Catholic Movement
description: A vote by the U.S. bishops was the most dramatic example of the conservative Catholic movement’s reach since Joseph R. Biden was elected. But the contingent had been gaining strength throughout the Trump era.
content: WASHINGTON — Pope Francis and President Biden, both liberals, are the two most high-profile Roman Catholics in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: What’s next for Iran’s nuclear deal.
content: Ebrahim Raisi, Iran’s ultra-conservative former judiciary chief, was elected president after a campaign that was widely viewed as engineered to ensure his victory. His win may give President Biden an opportunity to restore the 2015 nuclear deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Theater, Reality TV and What Is Stranger Than Fiction
description: Raja Feather Kelly’s “The Kill One Race” and “This American Wife” exist in a realm between, changing our relationship with what we witness.
content: There’s reality and there’s fiction: an easy distinction to make, right? Well things aren’t always so cut and dried, especially when we consider the performances we undertake in our real lives and the fictional stories that borrow from reality — the boundaries between what’s true and what’s false often get blurred.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: No Witchcraft, but Specter of Covid Shaped a Classroom in Salem, Mass.
description: A third-grade class in a historic town navigated a school year of loss and resilience shadowed by the pandemic.
content: SALEM, Mass. — It was late April at Witchcraft Heights Elementary School, and Roneline Ramoutarsingh was still feeling nervous about Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Just From the Back of His Head, I Immediately Knew It Was Him’
description: A flashback to past matinees, smiles on the No. 1 and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: She Never Saw Herself in Children’s TV Shows. So She Created Her Own.
description: For Chris Nee, the producer behind the popular “Doc McStuffins” series, diversity and representation aren’t nice-to-haves. They’re the things she wished TV producers considered when she was a kid.
content: — Chris Nee, producer of “Doc McStuffins”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Enrique Bolaños, Former President of Nicaragua, Dies at 93
description: A conservative leader who fought corruption and pushed for economic progress, Mr. Bolaños believed that his country was in a time of crisis.
content: Enrique Bolaños, the former Nicaraguan president who saw his predecessor convicted of corruption and drove economic development during a brief period of democratic transition, died on June 14 at his home in Masaya, Nicaragua. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Graham Norton Comes Around
description: The Irish entertainer is known for his freewheeling talk show, but in his novel “Home Stretch” he explores what it’s like for a gay man to return to his home and find both it and himself wholly transformed.
content: Graham Norton has been a saucy mainstay of British entertainment for so long that it is hard to imagine him doing anything else. Talk-show host, radio presenter, Eurovision Song Contest frontman, “RuPaul’s Drag Race UK” judge, he is known for being quick, empathetic and outrageous, and for relishing nothing more than a good dirty anecdote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Soviets Once Denied a Deadly Anthrax Lab Leak. U.S. Scientists Backed the Story.
description: The accident and a subsequent cover-up have renewed relevance as scientists search for the origins of Covid-19.
content: YEKATERINBURG, Russia — Patients with unexplained pneumonias started showing up at hospitals; within days, dozens were dead. The secret police seized doctors’ records and ordered them to keep silent. American spies picked up clues about a lab leak, but the local authorities had a more mundane explanation: contaminated meat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: George Stranahan, Benefactor of Physicists and Bar Flies, Dies at 89
description: A venturesome millionaire, he forged an only-in-America career in fields ranging from craft beer to free speech activism to scientific research.
content: For three summers in the late 1950s, George Stranahan lived in a remote mountain valley near Aspen, Colo., with his only professional tools a pencil and a piece of paper. He was a graduate student in theoretical physics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Iran’s System Keeps Its Grip, Despite the Chaos (or Because of It)
description: Governments rooted in revolution like Tehran’s have proved to be among the world’s most stable, even drawing strength from crises.
content: Since Mohammad Ayatollahi Tabaar was a child, he has heard confident predictions that the hard-line government of his home country, Iran, was doomed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Worried by Dirty Money, U.S. Examines the Secrecy of Art Sales
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 20, 2021.
content: “The only ones who know are you, the art gallery and God.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: In the Wake of India’s Covid Crisis, a ‘Black Fungus’ Epidemic Follows
description: The deadly disease has sickened former coronavirus patients across the country. Doctors believe that hospitals desperate to keep Covid patients alive made choices that left them vulnerable.
content: AHMEDABAD, India — In the stifling, tightly packed medical ward at Civil Hospital, the ear, nose and throat specialist moved briskly from one bed to the next, shining a flashlight into one patient’s mouth, examining another’s X-rays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man at Florida Pride Parade Is Struck and Killed by Driver
description: The police said on Sunday that the vehicle a 77-year-old man was driving “accelerated unexpectedly” as the parade began and struck two people in what investigators described as a “tragic accident.”
content: The driver of a pickup truck accidentally struck and killed one man and injured another as marchers were getting ready to begin a Pride parade in South Florida on Saturday, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Wondering if the Vaccine Worked? Get the Right Test, at the Right Time
description: Scientists generally recommend against antibody testing after vaccination. But for some people, it makes sense.
content: Now that tens of millions of Americans are vaccinated against the coronavirus, many are wondering: Do I have enough antibodies to keep me safe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Michael Gold
title: Adams and Yang tussle on questions of race in a frenetic day of campaigning.
description: The top candidates increasingly focused on race as they sought to assemble the broadest coalition.
content: Black leaders continued to raise concerns on Sunday about a new alliance in the New York City mayor’s race between Kathryn Garcia and Andrew Yang after the front-runner, Eric Adams, argued that the strategy was intended to dilute the voice of Black voters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Finding My Father’
description: A father’s mysterious disappearance fuels one writer’s quest for identity.
content: During his childhood, Nicholas Casey, Madrid bureau chief for The New York Times, received visits from his father. He would arrive from some faraway place where the ships on which he worked had taken him, regaling his son with endless stories. He had black curly hair like Nicholas’s and the beard he would one day grow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb and Marc Stein
title: ‘It Hurts’: Season Is Over Before Nets See How Good Big Three Can Be
description: Injuries kept the Nets from knowing what they could really look like once their stars — Kevin Durant, Kyrie Irving and James Harden — were playing well together.
content: Whether Kevin Durant, James Harden and Kyrie Irving could collaborate, share the basketball and play good enough defense to bring a championship to New York’s less heralded N.B.A. franchise were unknowns that nagged at the entire league.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Neil Vigdor
title: 9 Children and 1 Adult Are Killed in Alabama Crash
description: Eight of the children who died were returning from a beach vacation. A sheriff said the crash, which came as Tropical Depression Claudette plowed through the region, was the worst he’d seen in 30 years.
content: Nine children and one adult were killed in Alabama on Saturday afternoon when a van of children returning from a beach vacation and a sport-utility vehicle collided, and the van burst into flames, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Najim Rahim
title: Taliban Enter Key Cities in Afghanistan’s North After Swift Offensive
description: The setbacks come at a harrowing moment for Afghanistan, just as American and international troops are set to leave the country in coming weeks.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban entered two provincial capitals in northern Afghanistan Sunday, local officials said, the culmination of an insurgent offensive that has overrun dozens of rural districts and forced the surrender and capture of hundreds of government forces and their military equipment in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: N.Y.C. voters waltz into polling sites to cast early ballots as few lines are reported.
description: Wait-time maps showed delays of less than 20 minutes across the city, a far cry from that of November, when lines stretched blocks.
content: The scene in Manhattan on Sunday afternoon was a far cry from that of November, when lines stretched blocks as more than 1.1 million people cast early ballots in the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Here Come the Trustbusters
description: One of big tech’s top critics is now in charge of its regulation at the F.T.C.
content: Good morning and happy Juneteenth weekend. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: The Making of Team U.S.A. Track and Field
description: The stakes couldn’t be higher for participating athletes. Finishing in the top three — provided you have hit the time standard — means you’re headed to Tokyo. One misstep or miscalculation and you’re out.
content: Hundreds of track and field athletes have descended on Eugene, Ore., for the U.S. Olympic trials, which started Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: U.S. Preparing More Sanctions Against Russia, Sullivan Says
description: The national security adviser raised the issue of more penalties in the poisoning of Aleksei A. Navalny days after President Biden met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s national security adviser said on Sunday that the United States was preparing more sanctions against Russia in response to the poisoning of Aleksei A. Navalny, the country’s most prominent opposition leader, days after Mr. Biden attended his first face-to-face summit meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: ‘Here We Are, Again’: The Giants Stick to a Formula That Works
description: San Francisco’s dynastic threesome of Buster Posey, Brandon Crawford and Brandon Belt is enjoying every second (and every hug) of what could be its final ride together.
content: Look closely and you can still see glory floating like ticker tape in the wind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees Turn Their Third Triple Play of the Season
description: Three days after turning a first-of-its-kind triple play, the team went around the horn in the ninth inning to finish a win against Oakland.
content: Expected to contend for division and World Series titles, the Yankees have been maddeningly inconsistent this season, from their winning to their offense to their pitching. But in at least one unusual feat, turning triple plays, they have excelled, and their latest iteration, their third of the season, helped them secure a victory in dramatic fashion on Sunday at Yankee Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: With new opportunities and a different perspective, workers are leaving their jobs as the pandemic eases.
description: Millions of workers have voluntarily left their jobs recently, one of the most striking elements of the newly blazing-hot job market.
content: Millions of workers have voluntarily left their jobs recently, one of the most striking elements of the newly blazing-hot job market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: French Far Right Is Dealt a Setback in First Round of Regional Elections
description: A center-right party, Les Républicains, led the vote Sunday, while Marine Le Pen’s National Rally, which had high hopes, pulled ahead in only one region.
content: PARIS — French voters on Sunday inflicted a sharp setback on the far-right National Rally party in the first round of nationwide regional elections, dashing Marine Le Pen’s hopes of turning the vote into a springboard for next year’s presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ognian Georgiev and Ken Belson
title: The Pandemic Has Some of the Best Boxers Watching the Olympics From Afar
description: Boxers have had trouble with qualifying events being canceled because of the coronavirus. That led to some abrupt rule changes that left many athletes with no ability to adjust.
content: The Tokyo Olympics, already upended because of the coronavirus pandemic, which prompted a yearlong delay and heavy restrictions, is preparing for events in some sports to take place without the best athletes possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tamryn Spruill
title: Sugar Rodgers Is Rewriting Her Life Story Through the W.N.B.A.
description: Rodgers used basketball, and later her writing skills, to forge a brighter path after a painful childhood. The former All-Star is now an assistant coach for the Las Vegas Aces.
content: For much of Sugar Rodgers’ life, her job was survival: staying alive, healthy and out of jail in her Suffolk, Va., neighborhood, where the pop of bullets nearby forced her inside and away from the basketball hoop she loved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Virtue? A Fig!
description: Jacob Stulberg puts things into perspective.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — In my day-57D, I’m a bioethicist. I teach my students about different branches of ethics, like utilitarianism, deontology and virtue ethics (Virtue? A fig!), among others, and how to apply them to ethical questions about public health, medicine and science. Something my students always ask, again and again, is whether the revealer at 52A is true. Is there such a thing as universal moral truth? Or is it the case that what seems wrong in retrospect was actually morally right at the time? Can what is right in one country possibly be wrong in another?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: When the Local Paper Shrank, These Journalists Started an Alternative
description: An ambitious news site, The New Bedford Light, has sprung up in an old New England whaling town to fill a void in coverage.
content: When Jon Mitchell, the mayor of New Bedford, Mass., delivered his state of the city address in 2019, he made an unusual plea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: How Do They Say Economic Recovery? ‘I Quit.’
description: With new opportunities and a different perspective as the pandemic eases, workers are choosing to leave their jobs in record numbers.
content: At some point early this year, Justin Hoffman concluded that he was being underpaid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Koba Ryckewaert
title: After 35-Day Manhunt for Far-Right Soldier, Body Is Found in Belgium
description: Jürgen Conings, 46, disappeared after threatening the government and virologists responsible for the country’s pandemic response.
content: BRUSSELS — A 35-day manhunt in Belgium that involved helicopters, armored vehicles, 400 soldiers and police officers, as well as reinforcements from Germany and the Netherlands, culminated on Sunday in the discovery of a body believed to be that of a missing soldier with links to the far right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Front-runner Eric Adams says he is worried about release of early election results.
description: Mr. Adams is now taking aim at the city’s plans to start releasing partial and unofficial vote totals on Tuesday.
content: Eric Adams, the front-runner in Tuesday’s Democratic mayoral primary, is raising questions about the electoral process as his campaign faces growing efforts from opponents to slow his momentum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue
title: Delta Variant, Iran, Father’s Day: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Dumb Money No More: How David Ellison Became a Hollywood High Flier
description: When the young Oracle heir entered the entertainment industry, no one expected much. Instead, he’s built the rarest of businesses — a thriving, all-audiences, independent studio.
content: LOS ANGELES — Fifteen years ago, when a 23-year-old David Ellison rolled into Hollywood with oodles of trust-fund cash, entertainment insiders licked their jackal lips: Oh, the fleecing we will do!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Alexandra E. Petri
title: Giuliani embraces Eric Adams days before the primary. Adams says no thanks.
description: Mr. Adams did not seem particularly pleased and suggested it was an attempt by the former mayor to sabotage the campaign of a sometimes former critic.
content: Eric Adams may not want Rudy Giuliani’s support, but he got it anyway on Friday when the former mayor of New York City said that if he were a Democrat he would back Mr. Adams in the mayoral primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: As France Chases Title at Euros, Its League Faces a $400 Million Hole
description: French soccer teams could face economic disaster after a television partner said it would refuse to honor its contract. Transfers, salaries and budgets hang in the balance.
content: French soccer’s new television deal was supposed to save the league and its clubs from a financial meltdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: At the U.S. Open, a Three-Way Tie for the Lead Sets Up a Wild Finish
description: Mackenzie Hughes, Louis Oosthuizen and Russell Henley are knotted at five under par, but Rory McIlroy, Bryson DeChambeau and Jon Rahm enter Sunday’s final round as threats.
content: SAN DIEGO — There were plenty of intriguing story lines, but little sizzle, in the opening half of the 2021 United States Open. Richard Bland of England, who qualified for the championship by winning his first European Tour event after 477 failed attempts, was tied for the lead with Russell Henley, a PGA Tour veteran whose last tournament victory was four years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: Liz Cheney’s Unlikely Journey From G.O.P. Royalty to Republican Outcast
description: Dick Cheney always saw doomsday threats from America’s enemies. His daughter is in a lonely battle against what both see as a danger to American democracy: Donald J. Trump.
content: CASPER, Wyo. — Representative Liz Cheney was holed up in a secure undisclosed location of the Dick Cheney Federal Building, recounting how she got an alarmed phone call from her father on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anshel Pfeffer
title: This Is Still Benjamin Netanyahu’s Israel
description: Benjamin Netanyahu is out of office. But his legacy remains.
content: The days after Israel’s longest-serving prime minister was finally forced out of office have been anticlimactic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and James Gorman
title: Fight Over Covid’s Origins Renews Debate on Risks of Lab Work
description: Talk of ‘gain-of-function’ research, a muddy category at best, brings up deep questions about how scientists should study viruses and other pathogens.
content: At a Senate hearing on efforts to combat Covid-19 last month, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky asked Dr. Anthony S. Fauci whether the National Institutes of Health had funded “gain-of-function” research on coronaviruses in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Michael Gold
title: Garcia and Yang campaign together for a second straight day.
description: That two leading candidates would appear together days before the vote underscored how ranked-choice voting has complicated the mayor’s race.
content: Kathryn Garcia and Andrew Yang appeared together in Chinatown on Sunday ahead of a get-out-the-vote rally focused on attacks against people of Asian descent, the second display of unity between the two Democratic mayoral candidates in as many days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kat O'Brien
title: I Am Breaking My Silence About the Baseball Player Who Raped Me
description: A professional athlete raping a reporter is a story about power in our society, and how men wield it against women.
content: I was 22 years old and working as a sports reporter when I was raped by a Major League Baseball player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: In a Muffled Hong Kong, Bookstores Offer Freedom of Thought
description: Some independent shops flout the new limits on free expression. Others try to come to terms with them. For readers, they offer a sense of connection in a changed city.
content: HONG KONG — When Hong Kong public libraries pulled books about dissent from circulation last month, Pong Yat Ming made an offer to his customers: They could read some of the same books, free, at his store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Man’s Long-Delayed Quest for Degree Leads to Joint Graduation With Son
description: A man who was just a few credits from graduating from college nearly 30 years ago shared the commencement stage with his son last week.
content: When Juan D. Paneto was selected for a spot in a management training program at a bank in 1992, he couldn’t refuse. But there was a problem: He hadn’t finished school. Though Mr. Paneto had attended Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., for four years, he was still five classes short of graduation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Bipartisan Infrastructure Talks Collide With Democrats’ Goal to Tax the Rich
description: Many Democrats see the push for an infrastructure package as an opportunity to raise taxes on rich individuals and corporations. But resistance is coming from multiple directions.
content: WASHINGTON — In most years, the notion that Congress could pass a $1.2 trillion plan to fix the nation’s bridges, highways, tunnels and rail lines without raising taxes would be a politician’s dream, a vision of endless ribbon-cuttings with no angry cries of “tax and spend.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Juan Arredondo
title: Scorching Hot in Phoenix: What it’s Like to Work in 115 Degrees
description: Phoenix is facing a double heat and housing crisis that is falling hardest on people who have to suffer the sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: John Bercow, Central Figure in Brexit Drama as U.K. Speaker, Switches to Labour
description: Mr. Bercow was a lawmaker with the governing Conservatives before being elected speaker, a role in which he irked the governments of both Theresa May and Boris Johnson.
content: LONDON — The former House of Commons Speaker John Bercow, who gained international fame refereeing Britain’s political drama over Brexit, said on Sunday that he had quit the governing Conservatives to join the opposition Labour Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Yang
title: Being Superrich Doesn’t Make You a Superhero
description: The American idealization of wealthy mavericks isn't confined to the pages of comic books.
content: In the movie “Justice League,” there’s a moment when the Flash, a young and overeager Ezra Miller, asks the glowering Batman (Ben Affleck) what his superpower is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Try a new recipe for jalapeño-marinated pork chops, or for baked crispy fish with tartar sauce.
content: Good morning. Father’s Day, first day of summer, Bieber on the car radio as neighbors cruise to the beach: It’d be a nice one to cook outside if you can, or to pretend that you’re cooking outside if you can’t. I like these thin-cut, jalapeño-marinated grilled pork chops (above) for the menu, with their vegetal zing and cilantro thrum, topped with a red onion relish. Maybe some mango slaw on the side? That’d be nice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Milwaukee Bucks Eliminate Nets From N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Injuries to the Nets’ stars weighed on the team, which had been favored to win the championship this season.
content: The Milwaukee Bucks are headed to the N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference finals after defeating the Nets, 115-111, in overtime on Saturday night in a decisive Game 7 for their semifinal series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Leigh Brown
title: The Shakers Are Movers, Too
description: The country’s most significant collection of Shaker objects, out of public view for a decade, will relocate to an $18 million museum complex designed by Annabelle Selldorf.
content: CHATHAM, N.Y. — In an earlier life, the moribund red brick Victorian at the foot of Main Street in this thriving Columbia County village had been a sanitarium, a hotel and tavern, a furniture store and an auto dealership. These were the warm-up acts for its latest incarnation: a permanent new home for the Shaker Museum, widely considered the country’s most significant collection of Shaker furniture, objects and archival material. The museum, set to open in 2023 and to include a new addition, is being designed by the architect Annabelle Selldorf, whose current projects include the expansion of The Frick Collection in New York and an addition for The Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego La Jolla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Adams Clashes With Rivals on Last Weekend of Mayoral Campaign
description: Eric Adams and Andrew Yang tussled on questions of race in a frenetic day of campaigning, two days before the June 22 primary.
content: The leading candidates for mayor of New York City barreled into a frenzied final day of early voting on Sunday, a swirl of primary campaign activity marked by creative retail politicking and deepening acrimony between the race’s presumed front-runner, Eric Adams, and the rest of the field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: ‘We’re Not Back to Normal,’ but New Yorkers Savor Reopening Weekend
description: With virus restrictions lifted, New Yorkers had mixed reactions to ending the precautions they’d grown used to.
content: The lives of New Yorkers were marked by solitude and alarm during the worst months of the pandemic: Tens of thousands died, thousands of businesses closed and the city’s regular tempo screeched to a halt. But as vaccination rates have climbed, the city’s long hibernation has begun to end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Neil Vigdor
title: They Put Up a Pride Flag. A Homeowners’ Group Said Take It Down.
description: The Eastland Cove Homeowners Association in Broward County, Fla., said it was not on a list of approved flags. A couple face an initial fine of up to $50.
content: Mike Ferrari and Bob Plominski have lived in Eastland Cove, a small suburban development north of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for about 10 years. “We call it our little oasis,” Mr. Ferrari said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Brazil reported one of the highest Covid death tolls in the world.
description: The country reached 500,000 official deaths, behind only the United States and the presumed death count for India.
content: The Covid-19 death toll in Brazil has now surpassed 500,000, behind only the United States, which marked 600,000 deaths last week, and India, where deaths may range from 600,000 to as high as 4.2 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Scott Stringer makes campaigning a family affair on Father’s Day.
description: Mr. Stringer turned campaigning into a family affair on Sunday afternoon, when he, his wife and two sons canvassed on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.
content: A competitive and grueling mayor’s race does not take Father’s Day off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: ‘Evil’ Is Good and It’s Back for a Second Satanic Season
description: This stylish exorcism procedural by Michelle and Robert King moves to Paramount+ for its next 13-episode run.
content: Michelle and Robert King have a groovy split personality when it comes to creating television shows. On the more reputable side, they’ve brought intelligence and theatricality to a pair of highly regarded dramas about lawyers and politicians, “The Good Wife” and “The Good Fight.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Stop Hoping the G.O.P. Will Play Ball
description: Democrats are playing an honor game; Republicans are playing an endgame.
content: I am truly baffled as to why Democrats continue to search for bipartisan support that has not only been illusory, but nonexistent — with the exception of a predictable few and only on a few issues with them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Maxmen
title: Desperate for Covid Care, Undocumented Immigrants Resort to Unproven Drugs
description: Shut out from mainstream medicine, some immigrants are buying expensive, unproven Covid therapies from “wellness” clinics or turning to the black market.
content: FRESNO, Calif. — On a Tuesday afternoon in April, among tables of vegetables, clothes and telephone chargers at Fresno’s biggest outdoor flea market were prescription drugs being sold as treatments for Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 50 Reasons to Love Joni Mitchell's ‘Blue’
description: The singer-songwriter questioned everything on her fourth album. Twenty-five musicians speak about the LP’s enduring power on its 50th anniversary.
content: The singer-songwriter questioned everything on her fourth album. Twenty-five musicians speak about the LP’s enduring power on its 50th anniversary.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Guaranteed Income to Reduce Poverty?
description: Some like the idea, while others prefer alternatives like unionization and a federal jobs program. Also: The role of uncles; understanding touch.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 20, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 20, 2021.
content: A promotion on Saturday’s front page to a weekend New York Times for Kids section ran prematurely. The section will run in the June 27 editions.
source.name: The New York Times
